Mitigating CO2 emissions is a critical global objective. This study investigates the enhanced reduction of CO2 to ethanol using copper-doped bismuth vanadate (CuBVO) as a photocatalyst within a microfluidic system. Doping bismuth vanadate with 0.5 % and 1 % copper, resulted in significant improvements in photocatalytic efficiency, especially with 1 % copper doping. The reaction is driven under visible light-emitting diode using a microfluidic platform, where the thin film of CuBVO facilitates the CO2 reduction process. Gas chromatographic analysis confirms the generation of ethanol as a product. The results highlight the potential of microfluidic systems combined with perovskite-based photocatalysts for effective CO2 reduction. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Co2 reduction Thin films Copper doping Bismuth vanadate Heterogeneous photocatalysis Microfluidic system Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Global carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions from fossil fuel consumption surged in 2023 to a record high of 37.4 Gt, driven by unprecedented post-pandemic economic growth and slow progress in improving energy efficiency [1]. Intensive research reports are dedicated to developing materials that selectively reduce CO2 levels in the atmosphere and convert CO2 into value-added chemicals and fuels, which contribute to sustainable energy and meet increasing energy demands [2,3]. Starting from photocatalytic reactions with various nanostructured materials, perovskite-based photocatalysts have shown great promise for CO2 conversion into H2, CH4, CH3OH, and NH3, via complex photoreactions that harness solar photons as energy sources [4]. Thus, it is imperative to develop an efficient photocatalyst capable of being driven by visible light which is >43 % of the solar spectrum. Perovskite oxides (POs) are being studied and applied in many photocatalytic reduction systems for their good photoactivity, abundance and desirable band gap absorbing visible light [5]. In this regard, bismuth vanadate (BVO) has garnered attention given its exceptional advantages as a visible light photocatalyst, as it presents an adequate bandgap, simple preparation process, high charge transfer, and lesser recombination rates [6]. Different modifications of BVO have been reported due to low separation and transport of photoinduced electron-hole pairs, transition metals have been used to promote charge transport based on greater mobility of electrons and holes [7,8]. It is shown that copper-doped BiVO4 (CuBVO) acts as an electron/hole mediator for CO2 photoreduction reaction, promoting electron-hole separation and improving photocatalytic efficiency [9]. Recent studies have also supported the ability of copper to stabilize key efficient CO2 reduction (CO2R) intermediates and enhance CC coupling resulting in ethanol generation [10,11]. Additionally, integration of structured catalysts in confined microfluidic systems has shown promising results in enhancing reaction selectivity and efficiency [12,13]. Utilizing a microfluidic design for the cell exhibits advantages like higher surface area, lower energy requirements and higher flow dynamics. Together they offer promising prospects for efficient CO2R. Thus, the purpose of this work is to utilize CuBVO to develop state-of-the-art microfluidic photocatalytic cells and study their catalytic efficiencies for CO2R. 2 Experimental At first BVO was prepared by hydrothermal synthesis and later copper was doped at concentrations of 0.5 and 1 % using an impregnation method to obtain CuBVO. (SI 1.1). Later, CuBVO was deposited on the microfluidic platform as a thin film by air spraying technique. For analyzing the photoactivity of CuBVO, a photocatalytic microfluidic setup was designed that included an emitting diode lamp (Reflector LED, 20Watts, 6500k Color Temperature, Ip-65) that has an irradiation power of I 0 = 13.875 mW/cm2. One dark and light cycle each was performed using the microfluidic platform. CO2 saturated 0.1 M NaHCO3 was injected in this microfluidic set-up using a NE 1000 single syringe pump. The samples were taken at every interval for 5 h and the products were analyzed using gas chromatography (Nexis GC-2030, SHIMADZU). Material characterizations and fabrication of the planar microfluidic system are discussed in the SI. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 1 b shows the XRD diffractogram of BVO after Cu doping. The patterns show the characteristic peaks of monoclinic scheelite (JCPDS - 014-0688). A change in intensities and base width of CuBVO peaks was observed, this can be attributed to the possible change in morphology due to grinding applied during Cu doping. Furthermore, a slight shift to lower angles of the signal at 2θ = 28.8 corresponding to the (hkl) plane (−121) of BVO monoclinic scheelite is observed due to doping with copper. Lower 2θ shift indicates non-uniform strain induced in the BVO system with variation in the lattice dimensions (Fig. 1c) [14]. Fig. 2 d shows the Raman spectra, where the main vibrational bands are observed around 211, 336, 360, 646, 711, and 830 cm-1 that represent the VO4 tetrahedron [15]. Also, Cu-doped samples show a higher frequency shift in the VO stretching mode at 836 cm-1 with respect to undoped BVO at 830 cm-1, this is attributed to the replacement of some sites of vanadium by copper ions in VO4 tetrahedron. The above results can be corroborated with FT-IR characterization results (Fig. 2c) since changes are observed in the IR band at 744 cm-1, which corresponds to V O 4 3 − tetrahedron, showing a higher frequency change for CuBVO, which indicates that the structure variation of VO4 3- tetrahedron can be altered, this shows the incorporation of dopants into the lattice. From the UV–visible DRS spectra (Fig. 2a), the bandgap values of BVO, 0.5 %, and 1 % CuBVO were noted to be 2.4, 2.26, and 2.6 eV respectively. This demonstrates that the %Cu was proportional to the bandgap values, this is attributed to the surface doping of Cu allowing the formation of acceptor energy levels just above the maximum of the valence band [14]. SEM images (Fig. 3 ) reveal rectangular rod-shaped morphology for 0.5 % CuBVO and dumbbell shaped structures as well as an agglomerated circular morphology for 1 % CuBVO, which might expose the 010 and 110 facets on the surface of the crystals. The EDX spectrum (Table 1 ) reflects the proportion of Cu in the doped materials, being 1.48 % and 1.89 % for the 0.5 % and 1 % materials respectively. Photocatalytic CO2 reduction studies were performed using BVO, 0.5 % and 1 % CuBVO. The particles were transformed into ink using Isopropanol and then spray coated on a glass slide for microfluidic reactor fabrication (discussed in detail in SI). This set-up was efficiently utilized for CO2 reduction in the presence of an LED lamp. The liquid samples taken at each interval were then analyzed using Gas Chromatography. The chromatograms obtained from the CO2R experiments (Fig. 4 and S2.1) reveal conversion of CO2 to ethanol in experiments performed using 1 % CuBVO. A yield of 4.039 ppm of ethanol was obtained from 1 %CuBVO using the photocatalytic microfluidic system. This observation is similar to a study published by Xiang et al. [16], wherein doping of bismuth vanadate photocatalyst using copper resulted in generation of ethanol. To further benchmark our system, a broader comparison with other photocatalytic CO2 reduction systems is presented in Table 2 , which demonstrates the advantages of our setup such as its thin film architecture and effective visible light driven catalysis under mild conditions. The increment of photoactivity is attributed to the selective deposition of copper on 110 and 010 facets on the BVO particles, which leads to effective charge separation and improved photoactivity (high hydrocarbon generation). Facet-dependent CO2R could be the probable reason for the generation of ethanol in 1 % CuBVO particles. This can be confirmed with the XRD diffractograms of CuBVO (Fig. 1b) where the sample that shows the characteristic peaks of the 011 and 121 phases of BVO nanoparticles has higher photoactivity due to its higher charge carrier mobility and lower overall potential energy of O2 evolution [26]. Multiple factors could influence the resulting inability of 0.5 % CuBVO to produce CO2 reduced products, including the thickness of the photocatalyst thin film deposited and the CO2 gas purged into the NaHCO3 solution. The mechanism for ethanol formation in the CuBVO system likely involves a multi-step photoreduction pathway involving CC coupling of surface-adsorbed intermediates. Upon visible light irradiation, BVO generates photogenerated electrons and holes, which are separated more efficiently due to Cu doping. The copper ions act as electron mediators, suppressing charge recombination and facilitating multi-electron reduction steps [27]. Initially, CO₂ is adsorbed onto active sites and undergoes one-electron reduction to form the *CO₂ ⁻ intermediate, which is further reduced to *CO and *CHO species. The Cu dopant sites stabilize these intermediates, lowering the energy barrier for hydrogenation and coupling reactions. Two adjacent *CHO species may undergo CC coupling to form a *CH₂CHO intermediate, which upon sequential hydrogenation leads to the formation of ethanol (C₂H₅OH) [28]. Recent studies support this mechanism, reporting copper-facilitated pathways for C₂ product formation via the coupling of *CO/*CHO intermediates on bismuth-based photocatalysts [10,18,29]. The facet-selective exposure in CuBVO, particularly the (010) and (110) planes, further enhances the spatial separation of oxidation and reduction sites, promoting directional electron flow and improving ethanol selectivity [13]. 4 Conclusions In this work, we report the photocatalytic CO2R experiment performed in a microfluidic system in tandem with copper doped-BiVO4 particles. An initial dark cycle and one light cycle of CO2R experiments were performed and ethanol generation was observed in the sample doped with 1 % copper with a final concentration of 4.039 ppm. The results demonstrate that the photocatalytic capability of the particles can be enhanced by doping with metal ions and the application of a microfluidic system to reduce CO2 molecules photo-catalytically is possible. The planar microfluidic system not only facilitates efficient interaction between the particles and the CO2 molecule but also optimizes the reaction conditions through its innate small-scale advantages. The successful breakdown of CO2 molecules and generation of ethanol, a valuable hydrocarbon as a byproduct demonstrates the viability of applying CuBVO in practical applications aimed at reducing CO2. Further research focuses on modifying the microfluidic design and setup and exploring the scalability of the technology to further improve the CO2R reactions and improve the yield of the reduced products. coredata.dc:description: Mitigating CO2 emissions is a critical global objective. This study investigates the enhanced reduction of CO2 to ethanol using copper-doped bismuth vanadate (CuBVO) as a photocatalyst within a microfluidic system. Doping bismuth vanadate with 0.5 % and 1 % copper, resulted in significant improvements in photocatalytic efficiency, especially with 1 % copper doping. The reaction is driven under visible light-emitting diode using a microfluidic platform, where the thin film of CuBVO facilitates the CO2 reduction process. Gas chromatographic analysis confirms the generation of ethanol as a product. The results highlight the potential of microfluidic systems combined with perovskite-based photocatalysts for effective CO2 reduction.
